Items.Title: Petitions and Communications
Land Use Call-Ups

By The Chair of the Land Use Committee (Council Member Salamanca)
Pursuant to Sections 11.20(b-d) of the Council Rules and Section 197-d(b)(3) of the New York City Charter, the Council hereby resolves that the actions of the City Planning Commission on Application Nos.  C 220221(A) ZSM, C 220222 PPM, and C 220223 PQM (The Lirio – 806 9th  Avenue) shall be subject to Council review.  These items are related to Application Nos. C 220220 ZMM and N 220219 ZRM.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Landmarks, The Lirio – 806 9th Avenue, Manhattan (C 220221(A) ZSM, C 220222 PPM, C 220223 PQM, C 220220 ZMM and N 220219 ZRM)

Items.Title: Resolution to establish that the interest rate be four percent per annum for Fiscal Year 2023 for non-payment of taxes on properties with an assessed value of not more than $250,000, or not more than $250,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Roll Call.

Items.Title: Resolution to establish that the interest rate be seven percent per annum for Fiscal Year 2023 for non-payment of taxes on properties with an assessed value of more than $250,000 but less than or equal to $450,000, or more than $250,000 but less than or equal to $450,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments.

Items.MatterName: Establish that the interest rate be 14 percent per annum for Fiscal Year 2023 for non-payment of taxes on properties with an assessed value of more than $450,000, or more than $450,000 per residential unit for cooperative apartments.

Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Extending the rent stabilization laws.

Items.Title: Resolution determining that a public emergency requiring rent control in the City of New York continues to exist and will continue to exist on and after July 1, 2022.
Items.AgendaNote: Preconsidered - Adopted by the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 3 Council Members formally voted against this item: 
Council Members Carr, Paladino, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Borelli).

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by voice vote.
Items.MatterName: Determining that a public emergency requiring rent control in the City of New York continues to exist and will continue to exist on and after July 1, 2022.

Items.MatterName: Study and report on the trafficking of illegal firearms.

Items.MatterName: Requiring a survey of permanent firehouse upgrades to establish a working environment that facilitates use by a mixed gender workforce.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: Interest rates applicable to installment agreements for the payment of property tax arrears.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Requiring the department of education to create a plan for a pilot after school SHSAT preparation program.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer and Worker Protection

Items.MatterName: MTA to remediate any transportation structure, primarily elevated train lines, with extremely high levels of lead.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Women and Gender Equity
Items.MatterName: Childcare services at public meetings.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, S.5102/A.1475, which would allow municipalities and localities that have a senior citizen rent increase exemption program to establish an automatic enrollment program for eligible seniors to be automatically enrolled or automatically re-enrolled in the program.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Aging
Items.MatterName: Aging In Place Package - Municipalities and localities that have a senior citizen rent increase exemption program to establish an automatic enrollment program for eligible seniors to be automatically enrolled or automatically re-enrolled in the program.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Service and Labor
Items.MatterName: Pay Equity Package - Evaluation and expansion of diverse recruitment and retention within the municipal government.

Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Higher Education
Items.MatterName: Fair College Admissions Act (A.1423-A/S.1470-A)

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the City University of New York to compile data on bias incidents and hate crimes reported in the Jeanne Clery Disclosure of Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act into a single report, which should include greater specificity on bias classification, and to institute a campaign or initiative to educate students, faculty and staff about the rise of such incidents and how to report them.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Higher Education
Items.MatterName: City University of New York to compile data on bias incidents and hate crimes reported in the Jeanne Clery Disclosure of Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act into a single report.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Requiring the department of education to create a plan to provide specialized high schools exam preparation to all middle school students.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to establishing protocols for responding to students experiencing mental health crises
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Establishing protocols for responding to students experiencing mental health crises.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to penalties for failure to store waste in a satisfactory manner in required receptacles and for placing waste at the curb or on the street or sidewalk prior to the specified time for collection

Items.MatterName: Penalties for failure to store waste in a satisfactory manner in required receptacles and for placing waste at the curb or on the street or sidewalk prior to the specified time for collection.

Items.Title: A Local Law in relation to requiring the department of education to create a plan to administer specialized high schools admission tests on a school day
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Requiring the department of education to create a plan to administer specialized high schools admission tests on a school day.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting non-essential helicopters from operating at heliports owned or operated by the city
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Economic Development
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting non-essential helicopters from operating at heliports owned or operated by the city.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the fire department to plan and implement training on diversity, inclusion, anti-discrimination and anti-harassment
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Fire and Emergency Management
Items.MatterName: Requiring the fire department to plan and implement training on diversity, inclusion, anti-discrimination and anti-harassment.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to reporting demographic information of members of the fire department at fire companies and special operations units
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Fire and Emergency Management
Items.MatterName: Reporting demographic information of members of the fire department at fire companies and special operations units.

Items.Title: A Local Law in relation to information about health care services
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Hospitals
Items.MatterName: Information about health care services.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to child protective caseloads and workloads action plan
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: Child protective caseloads and workloads action plan.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter and the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to creating an office of sustainable delivery systems and requiring large generator of truck traffic buildings to produce and implement a delivery and servicing plan
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure
Items.MatterName: Creating an office of sustainable delivery systems and requiring large generator of truck traffic buildings to produce and implement a delivery and servicing plan.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure
Items.MatterName: Installing safety signs near schools.

Items.MatterName: Increasing reimbursements in Medicaid’s Federal Medical Assistance Percentage program for Puerto Rico and the other territories of the United States.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to extending the rent stabilization laws
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Extending the rent stabilization laws.

Items.Title: Resolution determining that a public emergency requiring rent control in the City of New York continues to exist and will continue to exist on and after July 1, 2022.

Items.MatterName: Determining that a public emergency requiring rent control in the City of New York continues to exist and will continue to exist on and after July 1, 2022.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to restricting the provision of eating utensils, condiment packets, napkins and extra eating containers, and clarifying the definition of third-party courier service
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer and Worker Protection
Items.MatterName: Restricting the provision of eating utensils, condiment packets, napkins and extra eating containers, and clarifying the definition of third-party courier service.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the fire department to annually report on equal employment opportunity complaints
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Fire and Emergency Management
Items.MatterName: Requiring the fire department to annually report on equal employment opportunity complaints.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to the democratic election of the New York City police commissioner
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting unauthorized surveillance by a global positioning system or similar technology
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting unauthorized surveillance by a global positioning system or similar technology.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of correction to assist incarcerated individuals in obtaining school transcripts, social security cards and driver licenses
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Criminal Justice
Items.MatterName: Requiring the department of correction to assist incarcerated individuals in obtaining school transcripts, social security cards and driver licenses.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to banning solitary confinement in city jails and establishing standards for the use of restrictive housing and emergency lock-ins
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Criminal Justice
Items.MatterName: Banning solitary confinement in city jails and establishing standards for the use of restrictive housing and emergency lock-ins.

Items.Title: A Local Law in relation to the creation of a task force to study, report on, and make recommendations to improve New York city housing authority’s engagement with tenants and to address tenant concerns about safety and quality of life
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Housing
Items.MatterName: Creation of a task force to study, report on, and make recommendations to improve NYCHA’s engagement with tenants and to address tenant concerns about safety and quality of life.

Items.MinutesNote:
The presence of a quorum was announced by the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers).

There were 51 Council Members marked present for this Stated Meeting.
The Majority Leader (Council Member Powers) presiding as the President Pro Tempore.
At this point the Speaker (Council Member Adams) made the following announcements:

Whereupon on motion of the Speaker (Council Member Adams), the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) adjourned these proceedings to meet again for the Stated Meeting of Thursday, July 14, 2022.

MICHAEL M. McSWEENEY, City Clerk
Clerk of the Council

The Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such reports, which were decided in the affirmative by the following vote:

The following files were removed from the General Order Calendar and voted separately:

M-63,  VOTE: 49-1-1
Negative: CM Yeger.
Abstention: CM Barron.

M-69 & Res. No. 254,  VOTE: 50-0-1
Abstention: CM Barron.

Preconsidered Int. No. 558-A,  VOTE: 48-3-0
Negative: CMs Carr, Paladino, and the Minority Leader (Council Member Borelli).

Res. No. 192,  VOTE: 47-4-0
Negative: CMs Aviles, Barron, Richardson Jordan, and Yeger.

Res. No. 193,  VOTE: 48-3-0
Negative: CMs Barron, Richardson Jordan, and Yeger.

Res. No. 194,  VOTE: 48-3-0
Negative; CMs Barron, Richardson Jordan, and Yeger.

L.U. No. 65 & Res. No. 252,  VOTE: 50-1-0
Negative: CM Barron.

L.U. No. 66 & Res. No. 253,  VOTE: 50-1-0
Negative: CM Barron.














See files for individual votes.

Items.MinutesNote: The Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such reports, which were decided in the affirmative by the following vote:

At this point, the Majority Leader and Acting President Pro Tempore (Council Member Powers) declared that the aforementioned items were adopted and referred to the Committee on Land Use and to the appropriate Land Use Subcommittee.
